transcript.speaker: Steve Inskeep
transcript.text: This Veterans Day weekend marks the 100th anniversary of the end of the first world war. It's a moment to think about how this country cares for veterans of many wars since. The Department of Veterans Affairs slipped into chaos earlier this year. Veteran Secretary David Shulkin was fired. He faced questions about his travel, but he said he was targeted because he resisted Trump administration efforts to privatize care. The VA runs a network of hospitals and clinics for millions of veterans across this country, so how the agency is run is a very big deal. This week we sat in the office of Shulkin's replacement - his successor, Robert Wilkie. When speaking before Congress recently, you said the state of the VA is better.

transcript.speaker: Robert Wilkie
transcript.text: Yes.

transcript.speaker: Steve Inskeep
transcript.text: That was your word.

transcript.speaker: Robert Wilkie
transcript.text: Yes.

transcript.speaker: Steve Inskeep
transcript.text: Why were you not able to say good?

transcript.speaker: Robert Wilkie
transcript.text: Because we're still in the process of assessing the condition of VA. I do think it is better because the turmoil of the first half of this year is behind us. The waters are calmer, but we're not where we need to be. But we're heading in that direction.

transcript.speaker: Steve Inskeep
transcript.text: And you're being pushed to change the agency in the way that it...

transcript.speaker: Robert Wilkie
transcript.text: Absolutely.

transcript.speaker: Steve Inskeep
transcript.text: ...Offers care. There's something that I want people to know about called VA choice.

transcript.speaker: Robert Wilkie
transcript.text: Yes.

transcript.speaker: Steve Inskeep
transcript.text: Would you explain what it is now and what you're trying to make it into?

transcript.speaker: Robert Wilkie
transcript.text: Well, VA choice has been superseded by the Mission Act. Mission Act does a few things. It opens the aperture for a veteran who seeks health care on his own terms - which means that if VA cannot provide the care that veteran needs and in a timely manner, that veteran will have the opportunity to seek care in the private sector.

transcript.speaker: Steve Inskeep
transcript.text: Help me understand the strategic idea. When you say that you're going to allow people to go to private doctors and the government will pay, are you supplementing the VA hospital...

transcript.speaker: Robert Wilkie
transcript.text: Yes.

transcript.speaker: Steve Inskeep
transcript.text: ...System, or are you thinking that in some...

transcript.speaker: Robert Wilkie
transcript.text: We're not replacing - this is not privatization. I do think, though, that - I'll give you an example. In the state of Montana - when you have families having to travel round-trip distances of 400, 500, 700 miles to get to a VA facility, we have to offer those veterans the opportunity to be served closer to home. We also have to address the reality of urban life, and I've discussed this with Senator Schumer. In metropolitan New York City, the crow's mileage may be awfully short, but it'll take hours and hours to get from point A to point D.

transcript.speaker: Steve Inskeep
transcript.text: Does the subway take you there or not?

transcript.speaker: Robert Wilkie
transcript.text: That's right.

transcript.speaker: Steve Inskeep
transcript.text: Sure.

transcript.speaker: Robert Wilkie
transcript.text: Absolutely. So we have to make VA a 21st century health care administration.

transcript.speaker: Steve Inskeep
transcript.text: One reason you had to answer that question about whether the intent was to privatize, of course, is because your predecessor in this office, as he was being removed, wrote of that fear, of that concern and said on our air that he thought that that was what he was being pushed to do - is to privatize, which he said was a terrible idea.

transcript.speaker: Robert Wilkie
transcript.text: Right.

transcript.speaker: Steve Inskeep
transcript.text: Was he just mistaken about what the president of the administration wants?

transcript.speaker: Robert Wilkie
transcript.text: Well, I'm not going to talk about predecessors other than to say I'm - I've been credited by members of the Senate with being a pretty good historian, and that might've diverged on revisionist history. No, and I've said it. You're not going to privatize this institution.

transcript.speaker: Steve Inskeep
transcript.text: No one ever had that intent?

transcript.speaker: Robert Wilkie
transcript.text: Not in my experience, and I certainly have never talked about that with anyone in this administration.

transcript.speaker: Steve Inskeep
transcript.text: There are three people who are said to be close to the president, Ike Perlmutter being one of them, couple of others, who, according to documents that were released through the Freedom of Information Act, did have a lot of contact with VA officials under the past secretary and were pushing the agency - were pushing VA in a particular direction. Do you talk with them?

transcript.speaker: Robert Wilkie
transcript.text: Well, you heard my testimony, and I said it under oath. I met with them when I was visiting the West Palm Beach VA, my first - I think it was my first week as acting and have not had any meetings with them ever - since that time.

transcript.speaker: Steve Inskeep
transcript.text: Do they write you? Were people around you?

transcript.speaker: Robert Wilkie
transcript.text: I have not seen any since then. I'll be clear. I make the decisions here at the department in support of the vision of the president.

transcript.speaker: Steve Inskeep
transcript.text: Was that a change then?

transcript.speaker: Robert Wilkie
transcript.text: You know, if you take ProPublica at its face value in terms of...

transcript.speaker: Steve Inskeep
transcript.text: Well, the documents are there. Yeah.

transcript.speaker: Robert Wilkie
transcript.text: Yeah. If you do that, then yes. It is a change from the previous leadership, but this is a much calmer institution. And I think it's in a much better place.

transcript.speaker: Steve Inskeep
transcript.text: Let me ask you about another thing. Our correspondent Eric Westervelt...

transcript.speaker: Robert Wilkie
transcript.text: Yes.

transcript.speaker: Steve Inskeep
transcript.text: ...Has reported on whistleblowers...

transcript.speaker: Robert Wilkie
transcript.text: Yes.

transcript.speaker: Steve Inskeep
transcript.text: ...Spoke with more than 30 people, current and former...

transcript.speaker: Robert Wilkie
transcript.text: Right.

transcript.speaker: Steve Inskeep
transcript.text: ...Employees of the VA...

transcript.speaker: Robert Wilkie
transcript.text: Right.

transcript.speaker: Steve Inskeep
transcript.text: ...Who reported severe problems with whistleblowers who call out issues with treatment.

transcript.speaker: Robert Wilkie
transcript.text: Right.

transcript.speaker: Steve Inskeep
transcript.text: And they're punished. Some are fired. Some have been put in isolation rooms. First, do you acknowledge there is a problem there?

transcript.speaker: Robert Wilkie
transcript.text: I don't - I'm going to tell you the truth. I don't know all of the individual cases. But we have numbers of investigations going on in our office based on observations and charges given to us by whistleblowers. I can't go into them, but there are many. And it is clear from my interaction with our whistleblower office that, for me, it's important that we protect them and that they're a vital part of how we right this...

transcript.speaker: Steve Inskeep
transcript.text: Is your starting assumption that you have a cultural problem with whistleblowers who are punished instead of listened to?

transcript.speaker: Robert Wilkie
transcript.text: Not - I have not seen that on my watch. Now, I've only been here a hundred days. And if there were that problem, I will - if I see it, I will move on that.

transcript.speaker: Steve Inskeep
transcript.text: It seems likely of the millions of people hearing you that some worked for the VA. It could be that someone in the audience right now is sitting on a fact...

transcript.speaker: Robert Wilkie
transcript.text: Yeah.

transcript.speaker: Steve Inskeep
transcript.text: ...That they find disturbing.

transcript.speaker: Robert Wilkie
transcript.text: And we...

transcript.speaker: Steve Inskeep
transcript.text: What would you tell them?

transcript.speaker: Robert Wilkie
transcript.text: Tell us. Tell us. We have an office, whistleblower and accountability protection. No other department in the government has that, not even the Pentagon.

transcript.speaker: Steve Inskeep
transcript.text: Does it trouble you at all that veterans' issues to some extent had been politicized...

transcript.speaker: Robert Wilkie
transcript.text: Absolutely.

transcript.speaker: Steve Inskeep
transcript.text: ...By your boss, by the president?

transcript.speaker: Robert Wilkie
transcript.text: Well, I don't think that - I think what the president has done is actually raise the valence of veterans' issues in a way that no other president has. I mean, no other president - and I'm a pretty good historian - on the campaign trail talked about veterans' issues as much as this president.

transcript.speaker: Steve Inskeep
transcript.text: Mr. Secretary, thanks very much.

transcript.speaker: Robert Wilkie
transcript.text: Thank you, and it's been a pleasure.
